head.title: The Case of Wen Ho Lee: The Questions Linger

hedline.hl1: The Case of Wen Ho Lee: The Questions Linger

abstract.p: Jerome A Cohen letter criticizes government handling of Wen Ho Lee national security case (S)

block.p: Your Sept. 26 note ''From the Editors'' about the Wen Ho Lee case did not review your coverage of two of the many troubling legal aspects of the case: the continuing denial of bail to Dr. Lee and the harsh conditions of his detention.

On Sept. 14, Attorney General Janet Reno stated that ''Dr. Lee had the opportunity from the beginning to resolve this matter and he chose not to, and I think he must look to himself.'' That is a view more often heard from those who preside over the Communist criminal process; their cardinal maxim is ''leniency for those who confess, severity for those who resist.''

Your Sept. 26 note ''From the Editors'' about the Wen Ho Lee case did not review your coverage of two of the many troubling legal aspects of the case: the continuing denial of bail to Dr. Lee and the harsh conditions of his detention.

On Sept. 14, Attorney General Janet Reno stated that ''Dr. Lee had the opportunity from the beginning to resolve this matter and he chose not to, and I think he must look to himself.'' That is a view more often heard from those who preside over the Communist criminal process; their cardinal maxim is ''leniency for those who confess, severity for those who resist.''
Moreover, other American officials admitted that Dr. Lee's detention was intended to stimulate his confession to spying by maximizing his discomfort.

The lesson is a familiar one. In seeking to protect our national security against a Communist government, we must not depart from the values and practices that distinguish our society from theirs. You should have looked more carefully into these questions.
JEROME A. COHEN New York, Sept. 26, 2000
The writer, a lawyer, is a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations.
